utterances: Very small.
Amongst orthodox Jews between 18 and 40, it was 79 percent.
Those people will largely take over the leadership of groups like AIPAC, the Anti-Defamation League, the American Jewish Congress.
It will move these organizations further to the right more and more to a position in which they support Israel, right or wrong, as a Jewish state not because of its liberal democratic value.
And that will further alienate the large majority of fairly secular, liberal-minded American Jews.
Alan Dershowitz, you just got back from a trip to the Middle East, where you met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Is there a serious concern there over the future of U.S.-Israel relations?
There is, of course.
I think Benjamin Netanyahu feels that he has enormous support in Congress and enormous support among the American public.
He frequently cites polls that show that support for Israel is actually going up, while going down among some liberal Jews.

Now, I think one of the reasons it's going down among liberal Jews is not that Israel is not as liberal; it's that the liberals and particularly the left radicals on college campuses have excluded Israel from the discussion and made it into a pariah state.
This is NPR News.

Peter Beinart, have you been surprised by the reaction to your article -Leon Wieseltier, for example, in the New Republic - that publication that you used to edit - called it an example of faux courage.
The head of the Anti-Defamation League, Abe Foxman, who we invited to be on this program with you, but he wasn't able to do so, has also lashed out at you.
Are you surprised?

What struck me about the piece is actually how much the intellectual debate has moved, how commonplace criticism, including harsh criticism, has become in the United States particularly in the blogosphere.
To some degree, I think that's very good.
To some degree, I actually worry that we are moving towards a situation in which the bi-national state position.
The position that there can be no two-state solution, but there should be one bi-national state between the Mediterranean and the Jordan River is picking up steam.

And it has made me even more concern that unless the major Jewish organizations define Zionism more broadly so that it includes the kind of critical Zionism, the passionately critical Zionism that Alan Dershowitz had advocated that, in fact, we will find ourselves stuck between an uncritical Zionism and the increasing non-Zionism of a one-state solution.
That's Peter Beinart.
He is the author of the article, ""The Failure of the American Jewish Establishment."" You can find it in the June 10th issue of the New York Review of Books.
We also spoke with Harvard Law Professor Alan Dershowitz.
Gentlemen, thank you so much.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Mark Twain could have had Jack Abramoff in mind when he said there is no distinctly Native American criminal class except Congress.
And Twain wrote that at the end of the 19th century.

Now, if it seems like our current crop of representatives are more prone to scandal and corruption, well, they've got nothing on the men and they were mainly men who served in Congress in the old days.
That's what Walter Shapiro thinks.
He's a columnist for Politics Daily.
And in an article in the online magazine In Character, he writes:
Contrary to media stereotypes, Congress may be more ethical than ever when it comes to a bedrock principle of honest government, the lack of overt bribery.
And Walter Shapiro is in the studio with me.
Welcome.
Thank you.
Okay, I don't want to pick on any one person in particular.
So let me just pick on many.
David Vitter, Charles Rangel, John Ensign, Eric Massa, I mean, it seems like the scandals and the ethics breaches are just so blatant now, but was it actually worse back in the day?
You can make a real argument.
First of all, ever since the Abscam scandal, where...
Of the early '80s.

Of the early '80s where FBI agents dressed up as Arab sheikhs and somehow managed to shake down congressmen, ever since then, I cannot think, with the exception of one congressman who had interesting containers in his freezer...
You're talking about William Jefferson in New Orleans.
Yes, who had a certain amount of money in the deep freeze, which was a little difficult to account for.
But aside from that, it's really hard to think of many cases like Spiro Agnew, where major politicians were getting cash in little white envelopes.
But, I mean, there was corruption.
I mean, there was...
Yes.
The 19th century, on the other hand, you had let's talk about everyone's favorite sort of 19th-century senator, Daniel Webster.
The great orator.
Yes, they wrote the short story about him that you're forced to read...
There are statues all over the city.

Well, periodically, Mr. Senator Webster got a little bored with the Senate and really talked about leaving the United States Senate for more lucrative professions, and every time he sort of made that announcement, the shipbuilders and the financiers of Boston really decided that the best way to keep Daniel Webster in the Senate was to send him cash gifts in honor of his sterling service representing Massachusetts' mercantile interests.
And that was allowed?
That was allowed.
It was I wouldn't say it was bragged about, but it was pretty common practice.
This was par for the course.
What do you think members of Congress from the late 19th century or the early 20th century would make of Congress today?
Would they view Congress today as a corrupt body, or would they see it as sort of a beacon of virtue?
Well, they would see both.
On one hand, they would be totally puzzled at the need for constant fundraising.
They would be a little amused at all these formal processes like ethics committees.

They would be absolutely appalled at the idea that sessions of Congress are televised, and they also would be a little troubled by the fact that the press did not play by the traditional rules that there are moments that are on the record and moments that gentlemen do not speak of.
You didn't talk about the sexual mores of members of Congress.
You didn't talk about episodes of public drunkenness.
These were things that were, for the most part there were exceptions were hushed up.
That's Walter Shapiro.
He writes a column for Politics Daily.
Walter Shapiro, thanks so much.
Thank you.
And Washington Post correspondent Spencer Hsu joins us to tell us what they found.
Welcome to the program.
Good to be with you.
At Scriba Meats, just down the road from the FitzPatrick nuclear plant, owner Rebecca Swenszkowski's grinding up their famous bacon burger.
It's got 4 pounds of bacon and 10 pounds of beef.
The nuclear workers make good money, she says.
The closing will cost the region $75 million in payroll alone.
They buy lunch and dinner here and luxuries, too.
Exotic game has become a big seller.
We got in the turtle, the alligator, the rattlesnake.
One thin rattlesnake fillet, by the way, 14 bucks.
Swenszkowski says everyone's going to feel the economic pain.
The trickle-down effect between our business, other businesses, people getting laid off, they're going to have to probably sell their houses, move away.
Nuclear is having better luck in other parts of the country.
Five new reactors are set to go online by 2020, all in the southeast, resulting in a 3,500 megawatt net increase in nuclear power nationwide.
Allison Macfarlane, former chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, says that's important because nuclear doesn't contribute to climate change.
Nuclear in the United States provides almost 20 percent of our electricity supply, and that's carbon-free.
